loans.name: Rufiji Group

texts.en:
Zaituni, who is in her late 30s, is married with six children who are still going to school. She has been running several businesses selling soft drinks and fruits and vegetables for one year now. She works from 7:00 am to 10:00 pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit. 

This will be Zaituni's 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase the soft drinks, fruits and vegetables and to start selling dry fish. She has paid back all of her loans successfully.  She used the profits to pay school fees and household expenses. She will use this to buy more dry fish to resell.  She dreams of building her own house.

Zaituni will share this loan with her loan group "RUFIJI", which consists of 16 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more soft drinks, fruits, vegetables and to start selling fish.

loans.name: Lan

texts.en:
Lan is a homemaker who manages the household tasks in the Ruessei Keo district, Phnom Penh. She is 33 years old and married with three children. She has a life partner with her husband, aged 35, who is a Tuk Tuk driver, earning an income around USD11 per day. Most of the income in Lan’s family comes from her husband providing transportation-based services, but it is not always a stable source of income. 

Currently, the motorcycle he uses for serving his customers is old and breaks too often, which is the reason that pushes her to take out a loan for the purpose of buying a good quality motorcycle for her husband. This will help Lan’s family to live a simple lifestyle and sustain their current business.

loans.use: to buy a good quality motorcycle for her husband's Tuk Tuk service.

loans.name: Gocha

texts.en:
Gocha, 50, is married and lives with his wife and two underaged children in the Ozurgeti district. Gocha runs his own trading business in his district. Specifically, he owns a store in the fair market where secondhand clothing and shoes are sold. Gocha also has a grocery store in the neighboring village and sells various groceries. He has been in the trading business for ten years and is very skillful in this field. He works hard all day long and his projects are profitable, which is why he’s decided to start another grocery store in his district, near the open market. The location is great, as it is always crowded, and according Gocha’s estimates it will be lucrative. 

With a loan of 4,100 USD Gocha will purchase a stock of basic groceries to start a store. He will hire the salesperson and generate additional income for his family's well-being. With determination and his loan, he expects to improve his income and give his family members what they need.

loans.use: to start up a grocery store.

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Jesca is 38 years old and lives in the town of Soroti in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has six children, who are all currently in school. For the past five years, Jesca has been working hard to manage her wholesale and retail shop, which sells sugar, soap and salt. 

To help expand her business, Jesca has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential items for the shop to sell, and will help Jesca to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. She hopes that in the future she will be able to increase the business. 

Jesca is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jesca who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase for more essential items for the shop to sell.

loans.name: Ani

texts.en:
Ani is from Vanadzor town, where she lives with her husband and two-year-old daughter. She has been re-selling clothing for two years already. Ani purchases clothing from the city market and resells it to the neighboring villages. The income that she gathers from this business helps her to cover the family's daily costs. By applying for this loan, Ani asks for financial support to be able to purchase new stock of clothing to sell to customers.

She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. The loan is very important for Ani, and she hopes for lenders' support.

loans.use: to pay for new stock of clothing to sell to customers.

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
31-year-old Annie is single and has three children aged between 8 and 12. They are currently attending school and living at home. She did not go to school, but she runs her shop business very well. With the loan proceeds she will buy more tissue, soap, soft drinks, toothpaste, etc. for her business. She said aside from fewer goods in her shop, she does not have any problem with her business. With a little money from her mother, she managed to establish this business 11 years ago. She learned this trade from other businesswomen. She enjoys the flow of her customers and their fast buying. 

Her dreams are to move from a small shop to store business and live a better life in the future.

loans.use: to buy more tissue, soap, soft drinks, toothpaste, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Aminadab

texts.en:
Aminadab is 34 years old. He is married with four children. He would like to use this Kiva loan to cover labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. He wishes to invest profits from his farming in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and cover labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Rawin

texts.en: Mr. Rawin is 30-years-old and lives with his parents. He is recently married. Rawin works together with his father in their fields. In 2009, he has taken a loan from Seva MFI and bought a truck to work on his own and for other farmers. He repaid this loan on time and now he wants to do rice cultivation on his own and needs a new loan of SRD 12,000 to purchase fertilizer and pesticides. In the future he wants to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides for his rice cultivation.

loans.name: Raj

texts.en: Mr. Raj is 52-years-old and lives with his mother. He is a rice farmer from an early age and he has inherited agricultural land from his parents. With the support of families from the Netherlands, he bought his tractor. Mr. Raj was previously financing his input by rice millers, who normally charge high interest rates and offer low prices. Since 2008, Seva MFI has financed his inputs, which resulted in more income and savings. With the savings, he has renovated his house and revamped his tractor. He asks for a new loan of SRD 7,500 to expand his rice production.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides for his rice cultivation.

loans.name: Awad

texts.en: Mr. Awad is 46-years-old and works as a security guard at night. During the day he is a rice grower. He has an extended family with five children, two daughters-in-law and two grandchildren. They all live together in the parental house. With the support of Seva MFI, Mr. Awad started agriculture in 2011. With the profits of the last years, he has bought a second hand tractor and extended his home. His goal is to plant more rice areas to have more income and take better care of his family. He needs a new loan of SRD 12,000 to purchase inputs for the rice production.

loans.use: To purchase diesel and seeds for his rice production.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a  Kiva borrower. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a retail store where he sells tomatoes. He describes his family challenge as lack of enough storage facilities. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy a water storage facility that will benefit four family members.They will be able to store sufficient clean water for domestic use. He hopes that in future he will sustain his family economically. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy a water storage facility.

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 32 years old. He is married with two children. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Buluhan

texts.en:
Buluhan is 33 years old and lives in the town of Nakaloke in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Buluhan has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells items like sugar, soap and salt. 

To help expand his business, Buluhan has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential items such as sugar, milk and bread for sale and will help Buluhan to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Buluhan hopes that in the future he will be able to stock more goods for the shop to sell. 

Buluhan is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Buluhan who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.


"


"

loans.use: to buy more essential items such as sugar, milk and bread for sale.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe    BENKADI est constitué de 5 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de36 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier  NIEBALA de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur 2éme prêt. Le précédent prêt  à été correctement remboursé. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  condiments à l’image de BALAKISSA qui est la femme du milieu  dans la photo. Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, 2 cartons de cubes de diverses qualités avec les grossistes de Bamako. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The BENKADI group consists of five married women who average 36 years of age and four children each. They live in extended traditional families in the district of NIEBALA, city of Bougouni. They know one another as neighbors and friends, and through their business activities. They joined the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution to strengthen their working capital and better conduct their activities. This is their 2nd loan cycle with the MFI. The first loan was correctly repaid. 

These women sell condiments. BALAKISSA, in the center of the photo, plans to use her loan to buy 2 cartons of various bouillon cubes from the Bamako wholesalers. She conducts her sales at retail, from her home and at the market, cash or credit, to a clientele consisting essentially of women. 

She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 15,000FCFA, which she will use to repay her loan and to invest in her activity.

loans.use: to buy condiments for sale.

loans.name: Horn

texts.en:
Horn, aged 55, is a fisherman working along the Tonle Sap River and also a farmer, growing rice and lotus. He has been operating in these businesses for nearly 23 years, making an income approximately USD 8.00 per day, which he uses for daily food and other home expenses. He is married and a loving father of three children, two of whom are still depend on his current income. 

As it is his second loan cycle, Horn will use it to invest into both farming and fishing business. He will buy fertilizers and seeds to apply to his crops. And he will also purchase fishing nets and gasoline for his boat. He is expecting a boost in his earnings and dreams of expanding his family-owned businesses. He is very thankful to lenders for financial support.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds to apply to his crops.

loans.name: Luz De Fe Group

texts.es: El grupo lo conforman cuatro socios de negocio uno de ellos es Isabel mujer de 35 años de edad, casada, su negocio es la compra y venta de cosecha desde hace 4 años, el crédito lo está solicitando para  la compra de cosecha de tamarindo. Jannette mujer de 48 años de edad su negocio es la compra y venta de cosechas desde hace 26 años, Yovanelia tiene la edad de 21 años su negocio es la venta de ropa nueva desde hace 6 años y Juan tiene 34 años su negocio es la compra y venta de cosecha desde hace 20 años.
texts.en: The group is comprised of four associated entrepreneurs, one of them is Isabel, who is 35 and married. She buys and sells different types of produce, whole harvests at a time, and has been doing so for 4 years. She asks for this loan in order to buy tamarind. The other members of the group are Jannette, 48, who has engaged in the same trade as Isabel for 26 years, Yovanella, 21, who has sold new clothing for 6 years, and Juan, 34, who has been in the produce trade for 20 years.

loans.use: to buy tamarind.

loans.name: Saramaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe    SARAMAYA est constitué de 4 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris, coépouses,  et enfants dans le quartier  HEREMAKONO NORD de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur 1ér prêt.Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  condiments à l’image de AISSATA qui est la 2 eme femme assise dans la photo de la gauche vers la droite. Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, diverses quantités de condiments   avec les grossistes de Bougouni. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The Saramaya Group is made up of 4 women with an average age of 26 years and an average of 3 children.  They all live in traditional, extended families with their husbands, other wives and children, in the Heremakono Nord area of the town of Bougouni.  They know one another through friendship, business and local ties.  

In order to strengthen their financial situation and grow their businesses, the women work with the field partner, Soro Yiriwaso.  This will be their first loan with this field partner.  

The women of the group all run businesses buying and selling spices, seasonings and ingredients, as does Aissata (second from the left in the photo).  Aissata will use her loan to buy various quantities of spices, seasonings and ingredients, from wholesalers in Bougouni.  She sells her products from home and at the market.  Her customers are usually women and she sells for cash or credit.  Aissata expects to earn a monthly average of 40,000 francs CFA which she will use to repay the loan and invest in her business.

loans.use: to buy spices, seasonings and ingredients.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a water tank of 6,000 litres.

loans.name: Ananias

texts.en:
Ananias is 56. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a single mother aged thirty six years old. She has two children one of whom who attends school. Margaret lives in Kyotera and she deals in a electronics business where she sells televisions, DVDs, woofers, radios, and many other electrical materials. She works 6 days per week and 14 hours per day. She said that she started her business in 2005. She also has rentals which supplement her family income.

Margaret started her business to earn a living and improve on the standard of living of her family. She has acquired this loan to add stock in her electrical business. Her clients are residents of Kyotera and traders from areas around Kyotera. Her future dream is to expand her business up to the level of wholesale. She faces the problem of high government taxes and lack of enough capital. She describes herself as a hard-working woman. She encourages lenders to reduce on the interest rates so as to enable even low income earners to have access to loans.

loans.use: to buy stock of electricals to sell in her business.

loans.name: Dancille

texts.en:
Dancille is 49 years old. She and her husband have been maize farmers for the past 18 years. Dancille would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from her farming, Dancille wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Mayela Guisel

texts.es: Mayela mujer luchadora y emprendedora tiene la edad de 29 años, casada, con dos hijos bajo su cargo, su negocio es la venta de ropa usada desde hace 4 meses, ella solicita el crédito para la compra de ropa escogida por docena como pantalones de damas, de niños y de varón, camisas, camisetas, blusas, vestidos, toallas de baño, shores, etc.
texts.en: Mayela, a hard-working woman, full of fighting spirit, is 29 and married. She has two children to raise. Four months ago, she started her own business selling used clothing. She asks for this loan in order to buy clothes she chooses by the dozen such as trousers (ladies', men's, and children's), shirts, T-shirts, blouses, dresses, bath towels, shorts, etc.

loans.use: to buy used clothing to sell.

loans.name: Irène's Group

texts.fr: C'est un groupe composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, nommée Irène (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 38 ans. Irène n'a pas fréquenté l’école. Irène est mariée à un certain Inoussa. Le couple a un enfant, qui n'est pas encore scolarisé. Irène vit ensemble avec son mari et son enfant. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Irène prépare du "Akpan (bouillie faite à base d'amidon de maïs, du sucre et du lait) à son domicile. Irène s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, et de fidéliser sa clientèle, Irène s’associe aux autres membres de son groupe pour solliciter un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le prêt antérieur a été bien remboursé.
texts.en: This is a group of three women who all live in the same neighbourhood.  The group representative is Irène (she has her hand raised in the photo).  Irène is 38 years old and did not attend school.  She is married to Inoussa and they live with their only child, who does not yet attend school.  In order to contribute to the expenses of their household, Irène prepares and sells "Akpan", corn patties that are dipped in sauce.  She buys her supplies at a market in Bénin.  This will be the second loan for Irène and the other members of her group.  They have requested this loan from the field partner, Alidé, to strengthen their businesses and retain their customers.  Their previous loan has been fully repaid.

loans.use: to buy maize, milk and sugar.

loans.name: Sahr

texts.en:
Pictured above is Sahr, a small-scale businessman base in Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. Sahr has come to SMT/Kiva lenders to apply for a loan of 5,000,000 Sierra Leon leones to boost the quality and size of his business.
 
Sahr is a native of Koidu city. The 52-year-old has been a businessman for 23 years now. He is currently selling electrical equipment/goods such as torch lights. 

The husband and father of five primary and secondary school-going pupils will use this loan in order to expand his business both in size and quality by buying a larger quality of electrical goods to add to his current stock.

loans.use: to buy a larger quality of electrical goods to add to his current stock.

loans.name: Recheal

texts.en:
Recheal is 50 years old and lives at Paynesville North which has the larger local market in Montserrado. She is a 4th grade dropout. She is married and her husband is not working. They have two children ages 4 and 21, only one who is in school and lives at home. 

Recheal described herself as a hardworking woman. Over the past ten years, she has been selling charcoal in the local market. She likes her business because of the ways customers respond to it. She started this business with money given to her by mother. She uses a bus to get her goods to her shop. She is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal for her business. She plans to expand her business. She says thanks to the lenders who continue to support BRAC Liberia to enable small business people to increase their business volume.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo has been engaged in a hog-raising business for more than ten years. He is 61 years old, married and blessed with four grown children. He is full of hopes in life.

Alfredo's wife owns a retail store and engages in a transportation business. The couple has been working hard to improve his hog raising and the retail store to make them productive and profitable.

To make his goal realistic, he is seeking a loan of PHP 30,000, allowing him to buy hog feed and vitamins. He knows that this additional capital will help to  make his hogs healthier upon reaching their optimum growth and enable him to get a greater price. He is hoping for approval of his requested loan amount.

loans.use: to buy hog feed and vitamins for his hogs.

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
Gregoria es productora de leche la cual vende a una de las empresas recolectoras de leche en la ciudad de La Paz; Gregoria  vive en casa propia, es madre soltera y tiene dos hijos, los cuales están en edad escolar, en la comunidad Tipampa del municipio de Achacachi, a dos horas  de viaje de la ciudad de La Paz, cuenta con cuatro cabezas de ganado  las cuales le proporcionan leche, que es el producto que le produce ingresos para mantener a su familia.

El crédito lo requiere para compra de una vaca lechera y así incrementar su producción lechera y sus ingresos para su familia.

El sueño de Gregoria es incrementar sus cabezas de ganado, aumentando la producción  de leche en su comunidad.
Es la primera vez que solicita crédito junto a IMPRO y la primera vez con KIVA.
texts.en: Gregoria is a milk producer. She sells milk to one of the distributors of the city of La Paz. A single mother, she lives in a house of her own with her two children, who are of school age. Her house is located in Tipampa, in the community of Achacachi, two hours away from La Paz. She has four milk cows, which are her only source of income to provide for her family. She asks for the loan to buy one more cow in order to increase her production and her income. Gregoria's dream is to buy more and more cows, so as to increase milk production in her community. This is her first time asking for a loan with the field partner and with Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a milk cow.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is 51 years old. He is a father of five children. He has been in the farming business for the past 15 years. 

He would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Sonja

texts.en:
Sonja is 32, married, the mother of two children, ages 6 and 10, who attend school. They all live in a small village in a minority community. 

Sonja works in a clinic doing administrative work and although her husband receives a pension from a company that he worked for prior to the war, he also does some agricultural work that he has been doing for many years. Together with her husband they plant corn and wheat and work on their neighbors' land when she has more time after her regular work and harvesting her own land. 

Sonja is requesting a loan in order to purchase a machine to help her better to work the land and be more efficient and effective. She is very grateful to Kiva lenders for the financial support given to her and she promises to pay her installments in a punctual manner.

loans.use: To purchase an agricultural machine.

loans.name: Viktorya

texts.en:
Viktorya is from Ijevan town. She lives with her husband and 25-year-old son. 

Viktorya runs a small shop where she sells various products. Viktorya's husband works as a taxi driver and his income is hardly enough for covering the family’s daily costs. 

Realizing that her business of running a shop is very important for the family, Viktorya wants to expand it. She has applied for this loan to purchase food products and provide a larger variety for her clients. She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. The loan is very important for Viktorya and she hopes for lenders' support.

loans.use: to pay for food products to sell to customers.

loans.name: Zimulinda

texts.en:
Zimulinda is 44 years old and lives in the town of Abaita Ababiri in the Kampala west region of Uganda. He is married and has 7 children with 5 of them currently in school. For the past 3 years, Zimulinda has been working hard to manage his bakery business, which sells bread and donuts. 

To help expand his business, Zimulinda has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more flour and other items to make bread to sell, and will help Zimulinda to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Zimulinda hopes that in the future he will be able to have a bigger bakery. 

Zimulinda is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Zimulinda who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to purchase more flour and other items to make bread to sell.

loans.name: Wangninan-Hinde 4 Group

texts.fr: Le groupement WANGNINAN-HINDE 4 est composé de dix personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, nommée Régine Fidèle (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 22 ans. Régine Fidèle n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Régine Fidèle est mariée à un chauffeur nommé Ange. Le couple a un enfant, qui n'est pas scolarisé mais à leur charge. Régine Fidèle vit avec son mari et son enfant. Les charges de ménages sont supportées par le couple. Pour ce faire, Régine Fidèle vend du charbon de bois à son domicile depuis un an. Régine Fidèle s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, et de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle Régine Fidèle ensemble avec les  autres membres du groupement WANGNINAN-HINDE 4 sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le prêt antérieur a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
The Wangninan-Hinde 4 Group is made up of ten people who all live in the same neighbourhood.  The group representative is Régine Fidèle (with her hand raised in the photo).  She is 22 years old and did not attend school.  Régine Fidèle is married to Ange, a driver.  The couple live with their only child who does not attend school, and together they provide for the support of their household.  To do this, Régine Fidèle has sold charcoal from her home for the past year.  She buys her supplies at a market in Bénin.  

In order to improve her business and meet the demands of her customers,  Régine Fidèle, and the other women of her group, have requested a second loan from the field partner, Alidé.  The previous loan has been fully repaid.

loans.use: to buy charcoal.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas is 27 years old. He has been a farmer for the past six years. He would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With the profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 23 years old. He is single and has been a maize farmer for the past three years. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to repair his lawnmower.

loans.name: Yah

texts.en: Yah is 31 years old, married, and has four children between the  ages of  4 and 10 years old. They all  live in Buchanan Ground Bassa County which is good at producing fish on the Liberian local market. She said she is good at managing her home and business. She has been running a cook shop (restaurant) for the past three years in the local market , and learned this way of selling from her mother. She requesting a loan to purchase  bitter ball (squash), oil,  pepper, rice, dry bush meat and  fish for her cook shop. She likes her business because her daily sales are high.  Her plan is to build a standard restaurant.

loans.use: to purchase  bitter ball (squash), oil,  pepper, rice, dry bush meat and  fish for her cook shop (restaurant).

loans.name: Tongor

texts.en:
Tongor is 44 years old and lives in Sanniquille, the capital city of Nimba County, which is rich in natural resources. The living conditions are much better than in the capital city, and it is the second most populated county in Liberia. 

She stopped her education in the third grade, and she is a widow and has five children between 14 and 29. Three of her children are in school. 

From selling her farm products, she was able to establish this business six years ago. She sells biscuits, milk, cream, and other items from a table market. She spends eight hours each day on her business. One problem she faces is small income, so she is requesting a loan to purchase more goods mentioned above for her business. Her plan is to one day own a shop.

loans.use: to purchase more goods for her business.

loans.name: Edouard

texts.en:
Edouard is 29 years old. He is married and has three children. 

He has been a maize farmer for the past ten years. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. 

With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Brisas De Holanda Group

texts.es: Ileana es una de las tres integrantes del grupo una mujer emprendedora de 27 años, casada, su negocio es la costura y venta de cosméticos desde hace 8 años, el crédito lo está requiriendo para la compra de cosméticos como perfumes de varón, perfumes de mujer, desodorantes, maquillajes, cremas corporales, cremas faciales, pinturas de uñas, tintes, etc. María Magdalena  es otra de las socias tiene la edad de 20 años su negocio es la venta de tortillas y María Auxiliadora su negocio es la venta de churros.
texts.en: Ileana is one of the three members of the group. She is an enterprising woman, 27 years old and married. For eight years, her business has been in sewing and in selling cosmetics. She needs this loan to buy cosmetics such as men’s cologne, women’s perfume, deodorants, make-up, body creams, facial creams, nail polish, dyes, etc.  María Magdalena is another of the group members. She is 20 years old. Her business is selling tortillas. María Auxiliadora’s business is selling churros.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics such as men's cologne, women's perfume, deodorants, make-up, body creams, facial creams, nail polish, dyes, etc.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace operates a beauty salon where she does hair treatment and offers other beauty services. Her biggest business challenge is the scarcity of water.

Grace is requesting her second loan from SMEP DTM for 26,500 KES, which she will use to buy a 4000-liter water tank. She will be able to harvest sufficient and clean rain water for domestic use. She hopes that in the future she will open another beauty salon.

loans.use: to purchase a 4000-liter water tank

loans.name: Gad

texts.en:
Gad is 56. He is married and they have three children. They all go to school. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 28 years old. He is engaged to be married and has a plan of having his own home soon. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a  Kiva borrower. She describes herself to be trustworthy. She operates a retail shop where she sells sugar, bread, cooking oil and other items. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of water storage facilities. She will use the KES 11,100 loan to buy a 1500 litre water tank to store clean water for domestic use. She hopes that in the future, she will open a big butchery and purchase a pick-up to supply meat. This is her fourth loan with SMEP DTM. Previous loans of KES 20,000 were repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy a 1500 litre water tank

loans.name: Ildephonse

texts.en:
Ildephonse is 43 years old. He is married with five children. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Juan Enmanuel

texts.es:
Juan de 31 años, solo logro estudiar hasta 7° grado, debido a que su padre lo abandono cuando tenia dos meses, y  a su mamá le toco ser padre y madre; debido a la pobreza decidió dejar de estudiar para  ayudar a su madre a  trabajar. Él esta casado y tiene dos hijos.   

Él  se dedica  a la agricultura desde que tiene 10 años, y fue con su mamá, y un vecino que aprendió el trabajo, además de la agricultura se dedica a la albañilería, y eso lo a prendió con un señor, que para ayudar a su mamá le daba trabajo, y comenzó mojando ladrillo, pero él trataba de ver como se pegaba ladrillo, y al ver eso el señor lo comenzó a dejar que pegara ladrillo. Hoy agradece a esa persona, pues de ese  trabajo esta  sacando adelante su familia. Hoy se esta probando con  la siembra de loroco, tomate, maracuya.  se levanta muy temprano para ordeñar  una vaca que tiene y luego se conduce al trabajo que le queda a unos 45 minutos, de su casa y su esposa se encarga de ir a dejar la vaca al potrero.    

El préstamo sera utilizado una parte para comprar una novilla y la otra sera para comprar 4 sacos de abono, 2 litros de herbicidas, 3 litros de foliar, 1 litro de fungicida para el hongo de la hortaliza.

Su sueño en un futuro, es comprar un carro para llevar a vender el producto que saca de la agricultura y que espera de la hortaliza, que sus hijos se gradúen en una carrera universitaria; ya que él no tuvo esa oportunidad, construir su propia casa por que donde vive hoy es de un cuñado.
texts.en: Juan is 31, and did not finish school, since his father abandoned his mother when Juan was two months old. His mother had to raise him all by herself, in poverty, which prompted Juan to quit school in order to work to help her. Juan is married and has two sons. He has been a farmer since he was ten years old, since he learned the trade from his mother and from a neighbour. He also works as a bricklayer, a trade he learned from a man who gave him work so that he would be able to help his mother. At the beginning, it was only simple tasks such as wetting the bricks, but Juan was always observing how the man actually laid the bricks in order to learn to do it himself. Upon noticing this, the man taught him how to do it. Juan is very grateful to this man today, since what he learned from him helps him provide for his family. He is now trying his hand at growing loroco, tomatoes, and passion fruit. He wakes up very early in order to milk the family cow and then commutes to work, which takes him about 45 minutes. His wife takes care of leading the cow to pasture. The loan Juan asks for will be used to buy a heifer, and, with the remaining sum, he will buy 4 sacks of manure, 2 litres of herbicide, 3 litres of fertiliser, and 1 litre of fungicide (this to rid his vegetables from fungi). Juan's dreams for the future are: to buy a car in order to take his produce to market (he has high hopes for his vegetables as well); to see his children graduate from university, a boon he himself was denied; and to build a house of his own, since the one he currently inhabits belongs to a brother-in-law.

loans.use: to buy a heifer as well as agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Gombre Group

texts.fr:
Mr SAYOUBA représente le groupe GOMBRE. Il est célibataire sans enfant. Mr est tailleur depuis
04ans. Il s’approvisionne au marché de son secteur en ville. Ses clients sont les amis et voisins. Mr
veut s’acheter 01 rouleau de popeline, 01paquet de fermeture et 01boite de boutons confondus. Il
épargne ses bénéfices. Mr ambitionne agrandir son d’activité et aider ses parents dans les charges familiales.
texts.en: Mr Sayouba is the representative of the Gombre Group.  He is single and has no children.  Sayouba has worked as a tailor for 4 years.  He buys his supplies at a local market in his town.  His customers are friends and neighbours.  Sayouba wants to buy 1 roll of popeline, 1 packet of zips and 1 box of mixed buttons.  He will save his earnings.  Sayouba would like to improve his business and help his parents with the family's expenses in the future.

loans.use: s’acheter 01 rouleau de popeline, 01paquet de fermeture et 01boite de boutons confondus

loans.name: Jose Amilcar

texts.es: José de 45 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposa y sus dos hijos, él se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras, piñas, plátanos, naranjas, tomates, cebollas, chiles, papayas,  entre otros,  tiene 10 años con el negocio y eso le ha regalado mucha experiencia en las ventas que le permite obtener las mejores ganancias, el lugar donde comercia es muy estratégico para la actividad y además muy concurrido de personas, ya tiene mucha clientela que lo prefiere porque su producto es fresco, a buen precio, de calidad y con un excelente servicio; José es un hombre emprendedor, dedicado a su labor con muchas ganas de salir adelante, siempre está buscando alternativas que le permitan alcanzar el éxito, en las últimas semanas aumento la demanda y quiere aprovechar para realizar una nueva inversión pero no posee de suficiente capital que la respalde por eso le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar frutas y verduras por mayor. Él tiene buenas referencias de pago, está agradecido con el apoyo y asegura que podrá saldar la deuda, a la vez confía que le dará a su familia una vida mejor.
texts.en: José, 45 years old, lives in a house of his own with his wife and their two children. He has been selling fruits and vegetables (pineapples, plantains, oranges, tomatoes, onions, chilli peppers, and papayas, among others) for ten years, owing to which he garnered a lot of experience in the trade, which enables him to make a decent profit. For instance, the spot he chose to sell his wares is very strategically placed and sees a lot of passersby. José has a loyal customer base owing to the freshness and quality of his produce, his fair prices, and his amiable manner. A very enterprising man, he is devoted to his work because he wants to improve his life. Thus, he is always looking for opportunities to be more successful. The last few weeks have seen an increase in demand, something which José would like to take advantage of, but for which he lacks capital. This is why he asks for a loan from the field partner, in order to buy fruits and vegetables wholesale. He has a very good credit history and is very grateful for the lenders' support. He assures us he will be able to repay the loan and is confident that he will manage to improve his family's lot in life.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables wholesale.

loans.name: Sergey

texts.en:
Sergey lives with his parents. For 5 years Sergey has been involved in the construction business. He provides renovation service to local people and earns his own and his family's living. As the only breadwinner of the family (Sergey's parents are retired), Sergey feels very responsible to work hard and bring in high income. 

While needing to purchase tools and materials needed for providing renovation service, Sergey has no money. He is asking for this loan and has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. Sergey hopes for lenders' support as it is very important for him to be able to purchase needed tools and equipment and provide better service to his customers.

loans.use: to buy tools and materials for providing renovation services

loans.name: Felicien

texts.en:
Felicien is 46 years old. He is married to a farmer. He would like to use his Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 


The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizer and to clean her farm

loans.name: Wendranigyande Group

texts.fr:
FATIMATA  est responsable du groupe WENDRANIGYANDE. Mariée, elle est mère de 04 enfants. Le plus  âgé a 14ans et le moins âgé a 06ans. 04 vont à l’école. 
Mme vend des plats plastiques, du savon et des tubes de pommades et de poudres depuis 10ans. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de son secteur. Ses clients sont les  femmes du quartier.
Mme veut s’acheter 04douzaines de différents savons.
Elle veut épargner ses bénéfices pour renforcer son activité. Ambitionne étendre les limites de son activité et subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
FATIMATA is the representative of the WENDRANIGYANDE group. She is married with four children aged 6 to 14 who all go to school. 

Fatimata has been selling plastic containers, soap, pomades and powders for 10 years. She buys her stock at a market in her district, and her customers are local women.

She wants to buy 4 dozen assorted soaps. She plans to save her profits to strengthen her business. Her goals are to expand her activity and provide for her family.

loans.use: to buy 4 dozen assorted soaps.

loans.name: Pingdwend Group

texts.fr:
MARIAM  est responsable du groupe PINGDWEND. Mariée, elle est mère de 04 enfants. Le plus  âgé a 16ans et le moins âgé a 05ans. 02 vont à l’école. 
Mme vend des pagnes et habits depuis 05ans. Elle s’approvisionne au marché de son secteur. Ses clients sont les  femmes.
Mme veut s’acheter 05 pagnes et 05habits bas.
Elle veut épargner ses bénéfices pour renforcer son activité. Ambitionne étendre les limites de son activité et scolariser ses enfants.
texts.en: Mariam is the representative of the Pingdwend group. She is married and the mother of 4 children, the oldest of whom is 16 and the youngest of whom is 5. Mariam has been selling pagnes (the traditional cloth of western Africa) and clothing for 5 years. She stocks up at the market in her region, and sells mainly to female customers. She would like to purchase 5 pagnes and 5 bottom outfits. She wants to save her profits to expand her business. Mariam's goals are to expand the boundaries of her business and to educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase 5 "pagnes" (traditional African cloth) and 5 bottom outfits

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is a first time borrower of UGAFODE Microfinance Ltd (MDI), applying for UGX 1,000,000. He is a single gentleman who operates a salon and Airtel money transfer business in a trading centre near Makerere University. He has managed to pay for his two sisters with his average income. His major challenge is limited capital to increase his float of Airtel money. There are many customers from the university who want his money transfer service and that’s why he is applying for the loan. His future plan is to work hard buy his own plot of land and put up a small commercial house in a nearby location so that he can shift his businesses and stop paying rent.

loans.use: To have more working capital  for a mobile money transfer business

loans.name: María Elena

texts.es:
María de 44 años, solo estudio 3° grado. Debido a la pobreza de sus padres, no pudo seguir estudiando,ella esta acompañada, y tiene 4 hijos pero 3 de ellos ya se encuentran acompañados y solo uno esta con ellos y actualmente esta en la escuela

 María se dedica al comercio en una tienda, desde hace 10 años, ella cuenta que la necesidad fue  la que la indujo al negocio, dice  que comenzó con 60 dolares, y que  la ganancia no se la comía; sino que la invertía en la tienda y cada día su negocio creció. Antes de  dedicare  a   la tienda trabajaba con su compañero en la agricultura, hoy solo se dedica a la tienda pues de esa forma a sacado su familia a delante. La tienda esta en su hogar de habitación,  se levanta a las 4:30 AM, pues bien temprano llegan sus clientes a buscar pan y otros productos.  

El préstamo sera utilizado para mejorar su negocio tienda, comprara 4 qq de maíz, 1 qq de azúcar, 1 qq de arroz, 4 cajas de jabón, 6 fardos de rinso, 6 fardos de lejía, 2 galones de aceite, sal, 10 fardos de papel  higiénico y otros productos.

Su sueño en un futuro, es tener una tienda fuerte, y poder darle a sus clientes un mejor servicio, que su hijo que esta estudiando se prepare, pues los otros no quisieron. Además, desea comprar un terreno y construir su casa pues donde vive hoy es de su mamá, con la ganancia, espera pagar el crédito a fundación campo, y tener las puertas abiertas.
texts.en:
María is 44 years old, she only went to school up to grade 3. She could not continue her studies because her parents were poor. She is in a relationship and has four children, three of them are already in a relationship themselves, and only one lives with the parents and is currently in school.

María has earned her living with a commercial store for ten years. She says that the need led her to take up her business. She started with 60 dollars and she did not spend the profit she made but invested it in her store, so that her business grew each day. Before she opened the store, she worked in agriculture with her partner. Today she works only in the store, because this is how she has brought her family forward. The store is in her home and she gets up at 4:30 a. m. because her customers come very early to buy bread and other products.

She will use the loan to improve her store. She will buy 4 quintals of corn, 1 quintal of sugar, 1 quintal of rice, 4 boxes of soap, 6 packs of washing powder, 6 packs of bleach, 2 gallons of oil, salt, 10 bales of toilet paper and other products.

It is her dream for the future to have a well-established store, to be able to offer her customers a better service and that her son, who is at school, gets a good education because her other children did not want to. Also, she would like to buy a piece of land and to build a house, because the place where they live now is the house of her mother. With the profit she hopes to pay back the loan to Fundación Campo and to keep her store running.

loans.use: to buy 4 quintals of corn, 1 quintal of sugar, 1 quintal of rice, 4 boxes of soap, 6 packs of washing powder, 6 packs of bleach, 2 gallons of oil, salt, 10 bales of toilet paper and other products.

loans.name: Slavik

texts.en:
Slavik is an experienced farmer from Shinuhayr village of Syuniq region. He lives with his wife. 

To take care of his family's everyday needs, Slavik is engaged in cattle breeding and in cultivation of wheat, beans, potatoes, beets, and alfalfa. He is also involved in processing agricultural products; he makes different soused vegetables and greens. 

Slavik’s wife helps him greatly in his everyday activities related to farming. They sell their agricultural products in the local market. The soused vegetables that Slavik and his wife make have high demand in Yerevan as well; several restaurants buy souse from them. 

To be able to run his agribusiness in a sustainable way, Slavik currently needs a loan of USD 2,700 to purchase agricultural products and containers for processing. The loan will help him sustain and develop his agribusiness. 

Slavik and his wife highly rely on the good will of the lenders for their good will in helping them collect the needed amount of loan to maintain and develop their agribusiness.

loans.use: to buy agricultural products and containers for processing

loans.name: Maria Imelda

texts.es: Maria de 55 años de edad vive en casa propia con su hijo y su nieto de 12 años de edad, ella se dedica a la compra y venta de chatarra como: aluminio, cobre, bronce,  plástico, hierro, etc. desde hace  3 años, comercializa su venta en su lugar de residencia, con lo que obtiene de sus ganancias y con la ayuda de su hijo logran cubrir algunos gastos de su hogar, doña Maria está solicitando un crédito para la compra de mas chatarra y así poder seguir con su trabajo y obtener mejores ganancias para tener una mejor estabilidad económica con su familia.
texts.en: Maria, who is 55, lives in a house of her own with her son and her grandchild, who is 12 years old. She buys and sells recycled materials such as aluminium, copper, bronze, plastic, iron, etc, and has been engaged in this activity for 3 years. She sells the materials at her house. With her income, and with help from her son, they both manage to cover household expenses. María is asking for a loan in order to buy more recycled materials to sell, so as to keep on with her business and to improve her income, in an effort to grant her family greater financial stability.

loans.use: to buy recycled materials.

loans.name: Virginie

texts.en:
Virginie is 29 years old. She is married and her husband works as a farmer. 

Virginie would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and to buy fertilizer during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With the profits from her farming, she wishes to invest in her business, so that in the future, she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). 

Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. 

Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more ferilizer and to support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Nare

texts.en:
Nare is a young farmer from Goris city of Syuniq region. She lives with her husband and three-year-old son. 

With the help of her husband, Nare is engaged in breeding livestock: cows, pigs, and piglets. Livestock breeding is the main source of family's income and is of great importance for them. 

As the family's needs are growing day by day, Nare needs to enlarge her livestock to be able to make ends meet. A loan of USD 3,000 will greatly support this young woman and her family, enabling her to purchase 13 pigs and some forage for the livestock. 

Nare and her husband hope to sustain and develop their agribusiness with the help of the loan. The family relies on the good will of the lenders and will be thankful to them for their support in collecting the needed amount of loan.

loans.use: to purchase 13 pigs and some forage for her livestock

loans.name: Dieudonne

texts.en:
Diuedonne is 41 years old. He is married to a farmer, and they have been in the business for the past ten years. 

He would like to use a Kiva loan to help pay labor costs and buy fertilizer during maize production.  He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. 

With profits from his farming, Diuedonne wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and help pay labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Matumaini Group

texts.fr: La cliente Faida est un leader adjoint du groupement d’affaire « Matumaini»,jeune, entrepreneur expérimentée, âgée de 38 ans  et mère de 7 enfants qui étudient tous. La cliente est vendeuse de manioc. Elle installe ses produits au marché public. Elle commença ses affaires avec le prêt de l’IMF Hekima, il y a plus de 9 ans. La cliente a déjà réalisé beaucoup de projets pour sa famille à travers les bénéfices de ce commerce. Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’accroitre son portefeuille en achetant 8 sacs de manioc. Ainsi, elle souhaite scolariser ses enfants et construire une jolie maison. L’insécurité (due aux rebelles et autres inciviques) dans les villages d’approvisionnement est un défi pour le développement de son activité. Au finish, elle remercie fortement Hekima pour son soutien en microcrédit aux petits entrepreneurs non bancables, pendant ce moment critique de guerre.
texts.en:
Faida is an assistant leader of the business group called « Matumaini». She is a young but experienced entrepreneur aged 38 and the mother of seven children who are all enrolled in school. She sells manioc and displays her merchandise at the public market. She began her business with a loan from MFI Hekima more than nine years ago. 

She has already been able to achieve a lot for her family using the profit from this business. This new loan will serve her to grow her income by buying eight sacks of manioc. In this way, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees and build a nice little house. The insecurity (due to the rebels and other predatory men) in the villages where she sources her goods is a challenge for the development of her activity. Finally, she thanks Hekima sincerely for its support with micro-loans to small entrepreneurs who have no access to banking services, during this critical wartime period.

loans.use: to buy eight sacks of manioc

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to hire farm hands and to pay for transportation costs for the harvest.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 40 years old and lives in the town of Mityana in the Mubende region of Uganda. He is married and has 2 children who are currently in school. For the past 2 years, David has been working hard to manage his hardware shop, which sells hardware items. 

To help expand his business, David has requested a loan of 2000000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more building items to sell in his hardware shop, helping David to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. David hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his hardware shop. 

David is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like David who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more building items to sell in his hardware shop.

loans.name: María De Lourdes

texts.es:
En la  parroquia Calderón de la ciudad de Portoviejo,  cada quince días se  reúnen las socias del Banco Comunal Desarrollo Femenino. Este lugar se lo conoce por su rica gastronomía y su vegetación,  la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y comercio en general.
En este lugar vive la señora María, tiene 35 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene tres hijos de 13, 10 y 2 años de edad, los mayores  estudian en colegio y  escuela. El marido es albañil. 
Doña María es una ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos se dedica a la venta de ropa por catalogo de la marca Leonisa y productos de Avon (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Trabaja cuatro días a la semana pero por horas ya que este es un trabajo en el cual no tiene horario fijo, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada semana. Tiene 5 años que se dedica a esta actividad con la cual se ayuda para darles una buena educación a sus pequeños ya que a su marido no le alcanza para esto.
Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, cosméticos y ropa interior. Lleva 4 años  en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los créditos le ayudan mucho para su negocio. Sus sueños son tener una boutique.
texts.en:
In the Caldeón parish of the city of Portoviejo, every two weeks the members of the Banco Comunal Desarrollo Femenino [Women’s Development Communal Bank] gather. This area is known for its delicious food and its vegetation.  The majority of people who live there work in agriculture and general trade.

Señora María lives in this area. She is 35 years old and has a common-law relationship. From her relationship, she has three children, ages 13, 10 and 2 years old. The older children study in school. Her husband is a construction worker.

Doña María is a homemaker. In order to earn her own income, she works in catalog sales of Leonisa brand clothing, as well as Avon products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes, and accessories for women). She works four days a week but as an hourly worker, because the work is of a type that doesn’t have a fixed schedule. She delivers her products on credit and collects payments weekly. She has worked at this for five years, allowing her to give her little ones a good education, because her husband cannot do so.

This loan is to buy perfumes, lotions, cosmetics, and underwear.  She has been in the Communal Bank for four years. She likes it because the loans help her a lot with her business. Her dream is to have a boutique.

loans.use: to buy perfumes, lotions, cosmetics, and underwear.

loans.name: Rafael Ángel

texts.es: Rafael, a sus 46 años de edad, vive con sus 2 hijos y su pareja sentimental. Durante 20 años se ha dedicado a trabajar como mecánico automotriz en su propio taller, trabaja de lunes a domingo desde las 7:00 am; además de prestar el servicio de mecánica también vende lubricantes y, de esta manera genera los recursos económicos con los que ha sacado adelante a su familia. El prestatario es amable, optimista y trabajador, siempre le encuentra el lado positivo a las diferentes situaciones a las que se enfrenta. Actualmente solicita el apoyo del crédito para comprar herramientas de trabajo (llaves, martillo, alicate, destornillador, entre otros) y surtir los lubricantes para la venta, esto le permitirá prestar un mejor servicio, de manera más ágil, pues tendrá los elementos necesarios, mejorando las condiciones de trabajo, además podrá ofrecer más variedad de marcas de lubricantes para satisfacer los requerimientos de sus clientes; todo esto dará como resultado un incremento notable en los ingresos que recibe por realizar su labor. Rafael manifiesta que su objetivo principal es seguir trabajando arduamente para tener la oportunidad de montar otra sucursal de su negocio en otro lugar y así podrá mejorar la calidad de vida y el bienestar de toda su familia.
texts.en: Rafael, who is 46, lives with his two children and his partner. For the last twenty years, he has been a mechanic, and owns his workshop. He works every day, starting at 7 am. He also sells lubricant. His workshop enables him to provide for his family. Rafael is amenable, optimist, and hard-working. He is always able to see the positive side of any situation that life throws at him. He is asking for a loan in order to buy tools he needs for his work (spanners, hammers, pliers, screwdrivers, etc.) and to buy more lubricant to sell. This will enable him to provide a better and quicker service, since he will have all the tools at the ready, thus improving his working conditions. His customers will also find a greater variety of brands of lubricant at his workshop. From all this, he hopes to see an increase in the income he derives from his work. Rafael says that his main goal is to keep working with all he has in order to establish a branch of his workshop somewhere else, and thus, ultimately, to improve the standard of living and the well-being of his whole family.

loans.use: to buy tools he needs for his work and to buy more lubricant to sell.

loans.name: Ishara Group

texts.fr: La cliente Bendera est un secrétaire rapporteur  du groupement d’affaire « Ishara», senior  entrepreneur expérimentée, âgée de 48 ans  et mère de 8 enfants qui étudient tous. Son conjoint est un commerçant de divers. La cliente est aussi vendeuse des articles divers (produits manufacturés).  Elle installe  ses articles au point de vente d’exposition publique, parfois à son domicile. Elle commença ses affaires avec le prêt de l’IMF Hekima, il y a plus de 3 ans.  La cliente a déjà réalisé beaucoup de petits projets pour sa famille à travers les bénéfices de ce commerce. Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’accroitre son portefeuille en achetant  2 bidons d’huile de table, 1 box du sel, 1 sac de sucre, 2 cartons de tomates en boite, 6 pièces de mayonnaises, 12 pièces de sardines, 1 carton de lotion de beauté, 6 paires de souliers, 1 carton de savons de toilettes, etc. Ainsi, elle souhaite scolariser ses enfants, accroitre l’entreprise et construire une jolie maison en matériaux durables. Les impayés et la vente en crédit sont des défis pour le développement de son activité. Au finish, elle remercie fortement Hekima pour son soutien en microcrédit dédiés aux petits entrepreneurs non bancables, pendant ce moment critique de guerre.
texts.en:
Bendera is the secretary of the Ishara group. She is an experienced entrepreneur, 48 years old, and a mother of eight children, who all go to school. Her husband is a merchant of various goods. Bendera is also a merchant of, [among other things], manufactured goods. She sells her goods in a public sales area and sometimes from her home. She started this business with a loan from Hekima more than three years ago.

Bendera has already completed many small projects for her family because of the earnings from this business.

This new loan will allow her to increase her stock by buying two drums of cooking oil, one box of salt, one sac of sugar, two boxes of canned tomatoes, six bottles of mayonnaise, 12 cans of sardines, one box of body lotion, six pairs of shoes, one carton of soap, etc. 

Overdue payments and purchases on credit are challenges to the development of her business.

Bendera would like to educate her children, expand her business, and build a nice house with durable materials.

Finally, Bendera would like to strongly thank Hekima for their dedicated support to small-scale entrepreneurs during this critical time of war.

loans.use: to buy various goods to resell

loans.name: Oluwatogni Group

texts.fr: Le groupe OLUWATOGNI est composé de trois personnes, qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe nommée Moïba (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 42 ans. Moïba est mariée à un certain Théonas. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et aucun à leur charge. Moïba n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Moïba vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Les charges de la maison sont supportées par le couple. Pour ce faire, Moïba vend divers articles (farine de blé, sachets, chaussures et des plastiques) et du charbon de bois à son domicile depuis environ dix ans. Moïba s'approvisionne dans sa région. Dans le but de diversifier son activité, Moïba s’associe aux autres membres du OLUWATOGNI pour solliciter un sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
The Oluwatogni group is made up of three people, who all live in the same area. The representative of the group is named Moiba (her hand is raised in the photo), and she is 42 years old. Moiba is married to a certain Theonas. The couple has two children, who all go to school. They have no [other people] under their care. Moiba did not go to school. She lives with her husband and her children. The couple takes care of the household expenses [together].

To meet these needs, Moiba has been selling various goods (wheat flour, bags, shoes, and plastic items) and charcoal from her house for about ten years. She procures her goods from the region.

In order to diversify her business, Moiba joined with the other members of the Oluwatogni group and they are now seeking their sixth loan with Alide. Their previous loans have all been repaid correctly.

loans.use: to buy various goods (flour, bags, shoes, plastic items) and charcoal

loans.name: Mingue

texts.fr:
Madame Mingue, âgée de 43 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants, est sociétaire d’un des guichets de IMCEC dans une région sis au centre-ouest du Sénégal. Elle a d’ailleurs eu à bénéficier de 2 crédits payés convenablement. Son activité consiste à vendre des bijoux, boucles d’oreille, chaine en plaqué…, la plupart du temps elle reçoit une commande avant de se lancer dans le marché, ce qui fait que sa marchandise ne reste pas longtemps invendus. Elle a une clientèle régulière. Mingue est une brave femme car elle appuie son mari dans la gestion de la maison. Elle met de l’argent de cote pour faire face à certains imprévus.
Elle veut associer la vente de produits cosmétiques a son commerce s’il a un fond plus consistant.
texts.en:
Mingue is 43 years old, married, and a mother of five children. She is a member of one of the UIMCEC branches in the central-west region of Senegal.

She has had two other loans that she has paid back.

Mingue sells jewelry, earrings, and metal chains. Most of the time, she receives an order before putting them up in the market, so her merchandise does not stay long unsold. She has regular customers.

Mingue is a strong woman, because she helps her husband with the household expenses. She [also] puts money aside in case of the unexpected. 

Mingue wants to also start selling cosmetics if there are is consistent funds.

loans.use: to buy jewelry, earrings, and metal chains to resell

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
Laura is a farmer from Gandzaqar village, in the Tavush region. She lives with her husband. 

To be able to take care of themselves, they are engaged in breeding livestock of cows, pigs, and hens, and in cultivation of grass. Laura's husband sells the agricultural products in the local market. Farming is the only source of income for the family. 

As the autumn is progressing, Laura needs to buy forage for the livestock. To reach that goal, she needs a loan of USD 400 to purchase grass as forage for the livestock. 

Laura and her husband greatly rely on the goodwill of the lenders and they will be very thankful to the lenders for helping them maintain their agribusiness.

loans.use: to purchase grass as forage for the livestock.

loans.name: Frodouard

texts.en:
Frodouard is 43 years old. He is married, with four children. 

He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and to buy fertilizer during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With the profits from his farming, Frodouard wishes to invest in his business, so that in the future, he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.
